conclusion: Understanding the circuit and given data including the movement of the conductor rod, specifications of lamps, and key condition.
The conductor rod ab moves to the right at a constant speed v in a uniform magnetic field B = 1 T.
The rails are parallel and separated by a distance l = 0.6 m.
The rod ab generates an electromotive force (EMF) due to its motion in the magnetic field.
Lamp L1 has specifications 3 V, 3 W. Its resistance is R1 = 3 Ohm.
Lamp L2 has specifications 6 V, 6 W. Its resistance is R2 = 6 Ohm.
The resistance of the conductor rod ab is r = 1 Ohm.
Lamp L1 lights up normally, meaning it operates at its rated voltage V1 = 3 V.
EMF generated by the rod ab moving in the magnetic field is given by E = B * l * v.
B = 1 T, l = 0.6 m, v is the speed of the rod.
Total resistance of the circuit is R_total = R1 + R2 + r = 10 Ohm.
Current I in the circuit is given by Ohm's law: I = E / R_total.
Voltage across L1 is V1 = I * R1.
Since L1 lights up normally, V1 = 3 V. Using this condition, I = 1 A.
Using the current I = 1 A and total resistance R_total = 10 Ohm, EMF E is E = I * R_total = 10 V.
From the formula for EMF (E = B * l * v), verify the speed v of the rod: v = E / (B * l) = 16.67 m/s.
Voltage across L2 is V2 = I * R2 = 6 V.
